newsitem.title: USA: Dow roars to second biggest point gain in history.
newsitem.headline: Dow roars to second biggest point gain in history.

text.p: U.S. blue chips staged a furious rally on Tuesday, propelling the Dow Jones Industrial Average to the second largest advance in its history.

The Dow industrials surged 173 points to close unofficially at 6834, a rally second in point terms only to the 186.84 point rebound that occurred two days after the Black Monday stock market crash of October, 1987.
With the gains, the Dow has now recovered more than 440 points or better than 60 percent of the nearly 700 points it surrendered between March 11 and April 11.

Despite the powerhouse performance by blue chips, analysts were quite cautious, eyeing instead a rather mixed performance in the broader market. Indeed, buyers today appeared extremely focused and largely shunned mid- and small-cap stocks.

"People are looking for companies with strong earnings and strong balance sheets," said Alan Ackerman, market strategist at Fahnestock & Co. "Money is moving towards predictability rather than projections."
Seasonal factors may have contributed to the sudden burst of buying, analysts said.

"A lot of the money we saw today is money that was put in retirement accounts by the April 15 (tax) deadline," said Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter Ltd. "And that money's going directly into index funds."

It was on April 15 that the Dow last managed a rally of this magnitude, posting a 135-point gain that then stood as the index's second best. Then, as on Tuesday, evidence pointed to a clear investor preference for safety over speculation.
"What's very clear in the composition of mutual fund flows is that investors have become more risk averse," said Doug Cliggott, U.S. equity strategist at J.P. Morgan.
"If you look at the past four weeks, 60 percent of the new money is going to income or growth and income funds," he said.
Such funds, and the stocks they invest in, offer a combination of healthy dividend yields and lower volatilty that investors crave during periods of instability, he said.
Investors clearly remained shy of high-growth sectors like technology and smaller-capitalization stocks that typically offer neither.
The result was a broad market that saw advancing issues only modestly outnumber decliners on the NYSE. On Nasdaq, there were actually more losers than gainers.
"This is not the recipe for a healthy advance," said Ralph Bloch, Raymond James and Associates' chief technical analyst.
Other analysts agreed, opting to wait for a clearer picture before predicting clear sailing.

"For this market to resume to the upside, it has to go back to the look and feel we had," said Gregory Nie, technical analyst, EVEREN Securities Inc. "That means it needs more volume and it has to resume the breadth it had."
Dow components AlliedSignal Inc, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Co, Coca-Cola Co and United Technologies Inc each rose more than five percent.

Drug shares were strong, led by Bristol-Myers Squibb Co, which jumped 3-5/8 to 63-1/2 after reporting first-quarter earnings that beat Wall Street estimates. Merck & Co Inc gained 2-3/4 to 89-1/4 and Pfizer Inc climbed 2-7/8 to 91-3/4.
Financial stocks also turned in a solid session, led by BankAmerica Corp, up 3-3/4 to 108-5/8, and Citicorp, up three to 105-1/2.
Eagle USA Airfreight Inc tumbled 8-5/8 to 21-7/8 after the company's second-quarter results fell short of Wall Street estimates.

Viacom Inc fell three to 27-3/8. The company said it would issue shares to track the performance of its Blockbuster video chain unit. It also said it expected a decline in Blockbuster's first-quarter cash flow
The S&P 500 index rose 14.24 points to 774.61.
The Nasdaq Composite rose 8.79 points to 1212.74.
The Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks fell 0.18 point to 338.09, and the AMEX Composite fell 6.51 points to 544.96, reflecting the weak performance beyond the large-cap arena.
((-- Wall Street desk, 212-859-1730))
